title: Strictly's Dianne Buswell likes tweet condemning judges' scoring as 'all over the shop'
text:

Strictly Come Dancing star Dianne Buswell has liked a tweet condemning judges' scoring as "all over the shop".

The dancer and her partner Dev Griffin were voted off the show this weekend and fans were furious with the judges.

The pair got a respectable score of 27, but the public vote crashed them into the bottom two and the panel failed to save them.

Many have accused the judges of making a wrong move, and now Dianne has seemingly agreed by liking a tweet criticising their scoring.

The message read: "I know the scoring is all over the shop it's mental!"

It was part of a string of tweets slamming the judges for sending Dianne and Dev home.

(Image: DIGITAL/EROTEME.CO.UK)

Another stated: " #StrictlyComeDancing can shove its result show up its a**e... how dev has gone home I have zero fucking clue, judges voting yesterday was all over the shop."

Dianne was so upset by the decision she couldn't complete the obligatory final dance and pulled out of appearing on the show's podcast with her boyfriend Joe Sugg after filming wrapped.

It comes after Dianne previously urged fans to stop trolling the judges over the decision.

Head judge Shirley Ballas has received a torrent of abuse and death threats since the episode aired on Sunday.

Yesterday, Dianne took to Twitter to reply to a fan who expressed concern over the trolling.

(Image: DIGITAL/EROTEME.CO.UK)

The viewers wrote: "Please sort your fans out @dbuzz6589 & @Joe_Sugg. I get why people are upset & I don't think it was @dev_101's time to go.

"But sending vile abusive tweets & death threats to @ShirleyBallas is totally out of order. Imagine if it was a member of your family on the receiving end."

Dianne replied: "Guys this is terrible you can not be bullying like this.

"'It’s awful and really upsets me to hear this. It's simply not ok and should never happen!"

(Image: BBC)

Earlier in the week, Shirley appeared on Loose Women where she claimed Strictly viewers were to blame for not saving Dev and Dianne.

Shirley said: "People have got to get out there and vote. We do our job. As you can see there were many people saved with lot lower scores.

"It's just so important. I respect everybody at home who’s been watching fifteen series. Everyone has a favourite. We do our job to the best we can.

"We have to do it right there in that split second on the one minute 20 seconds. We have to make a decision.

"The three judges were unanimous. It wasn’t down to me. It was unanimous and I agreed."
